<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 71, 92, 88]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 71, 599, 89]]<|/det|> A student investigates the cooling of hot water in a beaker. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 100, 410, 119]]<|/det|> The apparatus is shown in Fig. 2.1. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[260, 123, 732, 272]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 312, 144, 330]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 312, 920, 346]]<|/det|> The student uses a thermometer to measure room temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{R}}\). Room temperature is \(22^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 355, 494, 375]]<|/det|> On Fig. 2.2, show clearly the reading \(\theta_{\mathrm{R}}\). <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 388, 848, 448]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[462, 467, 534, 486]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 482, 920, 500]]<|/det|> [1] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 510, 146, 529]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 510, 922, 545]]<|/det|> The student pours \(100 \text{cm}^3\) of hot water into an empty beaker. She records the temperature \(\theta\) of the hot water in the \(V = 100 \text{cm}^3\) row of Table 2.1, as shown. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 555, 920, 604]]<|/det|> Without delay, she pours \(20 \text{cm}^3\) of cold water into the beaker. She stirs the water and measures the temperature of the mixture of hot and cold water. She repeats the procedure until she has added a total of \(100 \text{cm}^3\) of cold water to the beaker. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 615, 841, 634]]<|/det|> All the readings are shown in Table 2.1. \(V\) is the total volume of water in the beaker. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 644, 524, 662]]<|/det|> Complete the column headings in Table 2.1. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 644, 920, 662]]<|/det|> [1] <|ref|>table_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[455, 672, 541, 691]]<|/det|> Table 2.1 <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[351, 701, 648, 940]]<|/det|>
\(V/\)\(\theta /\)

12073
14065
16059
18054
20049

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 532, 88]]<|/det|>
A student investigates reflections in a plane mirror.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 101, 430, 118]]<|/det|>
A ray-trace sheet is shown in Fig. 3.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[138, 125, 848, 787]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[806, 781, 856, 826]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 842, 532, 860]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 3.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 870, 146, 887]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[161, 870, 918, 887]]<|/det|>
• Draw a normal to the line MR that passes through the centre of MR. Label the normal NL.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 883, 663, 900]]<|/det|>
• Label the point at which NL crosses MR with the letter B.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 897, 918, 930]]<|/det|>
• Draw a line 10.0 cm long from \(\mathbf{B}\) at an angle of incidence \(i = 40^{\circ}\) to the normal below MR and to the left of the normal. Label the end of this line \(\mathbf{A}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 931, 917, 948]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 71, 146, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 71, 779, 89]]<|/det|>
The student places the reflecting face of the mirror vertically on the line \(\mathbf{MR}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 102, 512, 120]]<|/det|>
He places two pins, \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\), on line \(\mathbf{AB}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 131, 920, 167]]<|/det|>
Mark the positions of \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\) with crosses (X) on line \(\mathbf{AB}\) at a suitable distance apart for this type of ray-trace experiment. Label the positions of \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 151, 920, 168]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 179, 141, 197]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 178, 920, 227]]<|/det|>
The student views the images of pins \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\) from the direction indicated by the eye in Fig. 3.1. He places two pins, \(\mathsf{P}_3\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\), so that pins \(\mathsf{P}_3\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\) and the images of \(\mathsf{P}_2\) and \(\mathsf{P}_1\) all appear exactly one behind the other. The positions of \(\mathsf{P}_3\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\) are shown on Fig. 3.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 238, 181, 256]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 238, 920, 256]]<|/det|>
Draw a line through the positions of \(\mathsf{P}_3\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\). Continue the line until it meets \(\mathbf{MR}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 240, 920, 257]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 270, 181, 288]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 269, 920, 301]]<|/det|>
Measure the acute angle \(\alpha\) between this line and the horizontal line \(\mathbf{MR}\). An acute angle is an angle less than \(90^{\circ}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 312, 920, 331]]<|/det|>
<form>\(\alpha =\) ................................................. \(^\circ\) [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 344, 146, 361]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 344, 920, 375]]<|/det|>
The student turns the mirror through \(180^{\circ}\). He draws a new incident ray at an angle of incidence \(i = 50^{\circ}\) to the normal above \(\mathbf{MR}\) and to the left of the normal.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 388, 920, 420]]<|/det|>
He labels the end of this line \(\mathbf{C}\). This line is **not** shown on Fig. 3.1. You may draw the line on Fig. 3.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 432, 920, 464]]<|/det|>
He places two pins on the line \(\mathbf{CB}\) and views the images of the two pins from near the top right-hand corner of the ray-trace sheet.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 94, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 71, 848, 90]]<|/det|>
A student investigates the relationship between the diameter and the resistance of wires.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 103, 420, 121]]<|/det|>
The following apparatus is available:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 135, 400, 152]]<|/det|>
• wires with different diameters

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 149, 547, 168]]<|/det|>
• instrument for measuring the diameter of a wire

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 166, 240, 183]]<|/det|>
• metre ruler

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 182, 235, 197]]<|/det|>
• ammeter

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 196, 237, 212]]<|/det|>
• voltmeter

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 211, 272, 228]]<|/det|>
• power supply.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 241, 702, 260]]<|/det|>
Other apparatus normally found in a school laboratory is also available.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 273, 796, 291]]<|/det|>
Plan an experiment to investigate how the diameter of a wire affects its resistance.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 295, 918, 338]]<|/det|>
Resistance \(R\) is given by the equation \(R = \frac{V}{I}\) , where \(V\) is the potential difference (p.d.) across the wire and \(I\) is the current in the wire.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 351, 536, 368]]<|/det|>
You do **not** need to write about safety precautions.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 382, 225, 400]]<|/det|>
In your plan:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 413, 131, 428]]<|/det|>
<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 413, 564, 428]]<|/det|>
draw a circuit diagram to show the circuit you use

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 428, 494, 445]]<|/det|>
• explain briefly how to do the investigation

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 444, 485, 460]]<|/det|>
• state **one** key variable to keep constant

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 459, 918, 492]]<|/det|>
• draw a table, or tables, with column headings, to display the readings (you are **not** required to enter any readings in the table)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 490, 598, 508]]<|/det|>
• explain how to use your results to reach a conclusion.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[435, 72, 561, 87]]<|/det|>
